text:
*Ahoy Content Strategists with portfolios!*

I’m making a UX content strategy portfolio.

I’ve done multiple projects for my last employer, including SEO, UX design, copywriting etc.

*I have questions:*
• Should I make just one project piece for my last employer (the strongest one)?
• Can I have multiple pieces from the same company?
• Do you know any really great portfolios someone early in their career can learn from?

elements.text: Ahoy Content Strategists with portfolios!

I’m making a UX content strategy portfolio.

I’ve done multiple projects for my last employer, including SEO, UX design, copywriting etc.
I have questions:
Should I make just one project piece for my last employer (the strongest one)?
Can I have multiple pieces from the same company?
Do you know any really great portfolios someone early in their career can learn from?

text:
You should consider all the work you are proud of in your portfolio. Treat each project separately as a case study. You can differentiate them by categories and tags.

BTW, while sending proposal to the prospect or sending resume for job application, only mention the relevant pieces of portfolio. 

Hope this helps.

elements.text:

BTW, while sending proposal to the prospect or sending resume for job application, only mention the relevant pieces of portfolio. 

Hope this helps.

text:
Thank you, Shahid! When you say “while sending proposal to the prospect or sending resume for job application,” do you mean my resume cannot mention anything other than the portfolio pieces?

e.g. If I have done an SEO writing project and a Newsletter project and I only have the Newsletter project on my portfolio, should I not mention SEO writing on my resume?

elements.text:
Thank you, Shahid! When you say “while sending proposal to the prospect or sending resume for job application,” do you mean my resume cannot mention anything other than the portfolio pieces?

e.g. If I have done an SEO writing project and a Newsletter project and I only have the Newsletter project on my portfolio, should I not mention SEO writing on my resume?

text:
Off course you can. 

I said the relevant pieces. It means all the relevant work to the JD.

text:
Query: What do you see as the difference between content marketing (for a brand), blogging (as a blogger/influencer) and writing a newsletter (i.e. as a personal creator on Substack)?

To me, it seems like newsletters on Substack have the potential to be the LiveJournal of today, but with the added Seth-Godin-ish bonus of building a community of like-minded followers.

Whereas blogging is for SEO and involves frequent, strategic, targeted posting, and content marketing is for SEO/thought leadership and involves longer pieces published less frequently.

Thoughts?

elements.text:
Query: What do you see as the difference between content marketing (for a brand), blogging (as a blogger/influencer) and writing a newsletter (i.e. as a personal creator on Substack)?

To me, it seems like newsletters on Substack have the potential to be the LiveJournal of today, but with the added Seth-Godin-ish bonus of building a community of like-minded followers.

Whereas blogging is for SEO and involves frequent, strategic, targeted posting, and content marketing is for SEO/thought leadership and involves longer pieces published less frequently.

Thoughts?

text: First, I’d encourage everybody to own their platform and not use substack, medium, etc. Really, your writing online could (should?) be done to build audience and community around your most owned platform (typically email)

elements.text: First, I’d encourage everybody to own their platform and not use substack, medium, etc. Really, your writing online could (should?) be done to build audience and community around your most owned platform (typically email)

text: I would say that blogging, newsletter, SEO, etc. is part of content marketing.

elements.text: I would say that blogging, newsletter, SEO, etc. is part of content marketing.

text: With the exception of maybe personal creators, virtually all of those other personas are creating content for a business reason.

elements.text: With the exception of maybe personal creators, virtually all of those other personas are creating content for a business reason.

text:
Agreed <@UUXMCJQ15>. It's so important for brands/businesses to own the platform. Otherwise you're at the whim of another company who can completely derail your strategy. Your site also doesn't get the SEO benefit.

If you're a thought leader/influencer or even a non-profit building a community, Substack is such an amazing tool. It solves the challenge of building the trust/authority needed to avoid SPAM filters. I wish it would have been around when I helped run Short Story Thursdays, a weekly short story "book club" delivered to your inbox. As we grew, the email-related challenges were unsustainable.

elements.text: Agreed

. It's so important for brands/businesses to own the platform. Otherwise you're at the whim of another company who can completely derail your strategy. Your site also doesn't get the SEO benefit.

If you're a thought leader/influencer or even a non-profit building a community, Substack is such an amazing tool. It solves the challenge of building the trust/authority needed to avoid SPAM filters. I wish it would have been around when I helped run Short Story Thursdays, a weekly short story "book club" delivered to your inbox. As we grew, the email-related challenges were unsustainable.

text:
<@URAV154AV> That’s exactly the kind of differentiation I’ve been wondering about; thanks for the input!

<@UUH2EB134> I used to run a newsletter on Substack, but I moved to my own blog because the brand of the newsletter became the brand of my business. But I’ve been thinking about doing more more thought leader/influencer content. Building a “tribe,” as Seth Godin would say.

elements.text: That’s exactly the kind of differentiation I’ve been wondering about; thanks for the input!

I used to run a newsletter on Substack, but I moved to my own blog because the brand of the newsletter became the brand of my business. But I’ve been thinking about doing more more thought leader/influencer content. Building a “tribe,” as Seth Godin would say.

text:
As Cassandra said, I think they're pretty interrelated. But blogging feels like the malleable middle ground here, where there's the most room to play. 

Most blogs are business concerns, either for a personal brand or company, and they might be filled with targeted, maybe even generic content. Everybody's got a blog. But the best ones amount to your description of content marketing. OTOH, some are for building/engaging with community. They feel more personalized and like newsletters.

elements.text:
As Cassandra said, I think they're pretty interrelated. But blogging feels like the malleable middle ground here, where there's the most room to play. 

Most blogs are business concerns, either for a personal brand or company, and they might be filled with targeted, maybe even generic content. Everybody's got a blog. But the best ones amount to your description of content marketing. OTOH, some are for building/engaging with community. They feel more personalized and like newsletters.

text: I am a fintech content marketer by day, but I’m a bookstagrammer/book blogger by night. For me, my primary audience is on Instagram, and my blog is a place for me to point back to previous content if I want to link to it again (I post all reviews on Instagram AND the blog), host referral links, etc. It just allows me to have a hub. I get a little bit of SEO traffic but that feels like a bonus. I also do a monthly newsletter for subscribers because they’re most engaged, and it feels like a gift for them.

elements.text: I am a fintech content marketer by day, but I’m a bookstagrammer/book blogger by night. For me, my primary audience is on Instagram, and my blog is a place for me to point back to previous content if I want to link to it again (I post all reviews on Instagram AND the blog), host referral links, etc. It just allows me to have a hub. I get a little bit of SEO traffic but that feels like a bonus. I also do a monthly newsletter for subscribers because they’re most engaged, and it feels like a gift for them.

text: Hey everyone, thanks for the great feedback. For context, I lead the content team at a SaaS company. Content is the backbone of our marketing team and the world pretty much revolves around how quickly we can put out content. Unfortunately this means a lot of pushing and asking for updates when I’ve already given timelines. Our wider team understands that we are going as fast as we can, and that our content is great and really important, but they get so impatient and I don’t know how to communicate it in any other way than just like, leave us alone and let us work. The timelines are visible to everyone, I update constantly, there’s just this constant push from people who have no idea how long it takes to make things to go faster because they want to get to their job of promotion and implementing in our campaigns. They will come back to us all the time with like, hey can we get this done by tomorrow or let’s launch this campaign on Friday and we’re laughing because it’s just insane. I don’t know how to get people to listen and understand, and I waste a lot of time explaining to people every week that the timelines are there and that’s when things get done. I imagine part of is them feeling pressure and wanting to get started so they can start reporting results, and I can empathize with that, but it’s really stressing out my team and they are starting to be demoralized by this constant push and lack of respect.

elements.text: Hey everyone, thanks for the great feedback. For context, I lead the content team at a SaaS company. Content is the backbone of our marketing team and the world pretty much revolves around how quickly we can put out content. Unfortunately this means a lot of pushing and asking for updates when I’ve already given timelines. Our wider team understands that we are going as fast as we can, and that our content is great and really important, but they get so impatient and I don’t know how to communicate it in any other way than just like, leave us alone and let us work. The timelines are visible to everyone, I update constantly, there’s just this constant push from people who have no idea how long it takes to make things to go faster because they want to get to their job of promotion and implementing in our campaigns. They will come back to us all the time with like, hey can we get this done by tomorrow or let’s launch this campaign on Friday and we’re laughing because it’s just insane. I don’t know how to get people to listen and understand, and I waste a lot of time explaining to people every week that the timelines are there and that’s when things get done. I imagine part of is them feeling pressure and wanting to get started so they can start reporting results, and I can empathize with that, but it’s really stressing out my team and they are starting to be demoralized by this constant push and lack of respect.

text: From a campaign perspective hopefully they can understand if y'all rush out content you're only diluting your ad spend.
